texts.definition: The abstract attributes and characteristics associated with a player of a game.
markups: <style="Definition">The abstract attributes and characteristics associated with a player of a game.</style>

Many games divide gameplay into events taking place in a game world and abstract entities handling attributes and possible actions. Those entities in the latter group that are under player control are <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>.

The financial empires built and destroyed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monopoly">Monopoly</link></style> can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>, consisting of the money and land deeds players have (and the latter may or may not be mortgaged). Grand strategy games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> let players take control over civilizations or countries.

The empires built in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, the colonies constructed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>, the farms developed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Agricola">Agricola</link></style>, and the mountain uplifted in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Erosion">Erosion</link></style> are all <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> since they are not part of one game world (even if the represent parts of it). Similarly, the abilities developed for species in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ursuppe">Ursuppe</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spore">Spore</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/American%20Megafauna">American Megafauna</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>, as are the technologies developed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Origins:%20How%20We%20Became%20Human">Origins: How We Became Human</link></style>.

The people played in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, are <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> but are usually simply called <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. The third edition of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> does add another type of <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> -  ''party sheets'' representing the type of group the players are and which provides specific abilities to them.

The various "colors" collected in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pik-Min%20series">Pik-Min series</link></style> to create new ''Pik-Mins'' is a vital part of a player's current game state, and as associated to him or her an <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Construct</style>.

While what types of information is a prime concern for the design of <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>, a likewise important aspect is how they connect to how players can affect <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> is one of the most basic pieces of information stored, as is <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>. However, games which challenge players by continuously providing <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> and not using global <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> not putting hard limits on <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> can create a version of <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> by having which <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> players have completed in the <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>, so the patterns can multiple ways of being able to affect each other.

<style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are a special case of <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> that are often tied to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. They distinguish themselves from other <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> in often being more detailed, either to support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> or being parts of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. Another noteworthy aspect of them is that they are also the most common example, through <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, of abstract constructs that are not under some form of player control. Besides <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, other examples of ways <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> can be connected to <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> is how they change the abilities and possible actions of <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> (see e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style>) or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> (see e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ursuppe">Ursuppe</link></style>).

Typical parts of <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> include <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> (e.g. money and manpower), <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technologies">Technologies</link></style>, and other <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> is an example of a game that has the last structure - here civilizations are <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> that contain cities (and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> from the fourth installment of the series) that in turn also are <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>. While <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> do not make use of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> as regularly as <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> do, it can more often be feasible to make use of <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, as for example the collecting of the various "colors" in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pik-Min%20series">Pik-Min series</link></style> shows an example of. <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> are basically <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> focused upon encouraging or supporting <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style> allow players to create these before gameplay. These are also an example of how players can be given the possibility of applying <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> on <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> may be stored digitally in computer-based games, other games make use of tangible game elements. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style> are common for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, but for other types of <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> an option is using collections of <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>. Examples of games that make use of <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> for this purpose include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Erosion">Erosion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ursuppe">Ursuppe</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/American%20Megafauna">American Megafauna</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Origins:%20How%20We%20Became%20Human">Origins: How We Became Human</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> does the same with <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> placed on a private game board.

While <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> in general may not allow the same personalization as <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, they relatively often support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style> and can often become more powerful during gameplay through <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>. There are many options for providing such development, including: <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bag-management">Bag Management</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technologies">Technologies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Such development may give them <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> but these may also be given to the <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> before gameplay begins. They are also not so often used together with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are, but when they are the same design options as those described under <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are possible. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maintenance%20Costs">Maintenance Costs</link></style> are however a design choice not occurring as often in <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as in <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>.

Somewhat paradoxically, that <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> do not exist themselves in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> help provide <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> in these. This since there are many things one cannot directly observe in the real world, and not being able to do this in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> adds this similarity to a game.

The information contained in <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style>. One example of how this can be done exists in the ''ledgers'' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style>; these show both current and historical overviews of a country's statistics as well as comparisons to other countries of some types of statistics.

While <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> in themselves do usually not support narratives, this is more common for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, the retelling of an <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> during a game instance creates a narrative.

<style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> let <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> have more complexity than can be represented by the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> themselves, and thereby modulate these. When players can have some control and foresight into the <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>, i.e. have the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to make <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> into them, this leads to <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> (if players have some <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> regarding the development) and a way for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Time%20Investments">Player Time Investments</link></style>. However, games that allow or require players to interact with <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> often can be perceived as forcing them to engage in <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> can easily become reasons for player <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> since the state or development of these often represent the level of success or failure for players.

In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style> which provide different types of <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> create <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>; this is for example done through the combination of choices regarding leader and civilization in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>. Providing <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> for different <style="CurrentLink">Abstract Player Constructs</style>, as done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style>, is a way to provide <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> but also causes disruptions in <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.
